bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 1, 1875

div1.p: Reed informs Emilie Lawrence that he has light military duties and an easy command as a medical officer at Willets Point U.S. Army base. He misses her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 1, 1875
div1.p:
I sincerely
hope that the morning is as
bright and beautiful at Murfrees-
boro as it is at Willet's Point-
I have never enjoyed a morning
more than this one; (of course I
except all of those spent in your
society.) Just after breakfast, I
arrayed myself in full-dress u-
niform, and in company with
General Abbott & other officers
visited the Soldiers quarters, &
all the buildings connected with
with the Post, all of which were
subjected to a rigid inspection-
This is what is called “Short In-
spection-” On next Sunday, we
have “Long Inspection;” that is, besides
an inspection of all the buildings,
(officers' quarters excluded) there
is a full-dress parade lasting
an hour or more. I am re-
quired to take part in it, but
my drilling amounts to very
little. I assure you, I appre-
ciate exemption from drill duty,
during the week, to its fullest
extent. I sit on my veranda &,
while listening to the sweet
strains of music, watch the
companies go through their
various military evolutions
with a good deal of interest.
I never knew what privileges
the medical Profession secured
before, but I am fully con-
vinced, at present, that they are
invaluable, & the profession has
accordingly risen in my es-
timation. With your permission,
I don't think I'll be a prea-
cher!- This by the way, however --
I have now spent my first
week here and I candidly tell
you that I am better satis-
fied than I had anticipated-
Of course, I do not expect such
a comfortable Post when I
next receive orders, but I
am pretty sure that I will
be contented wherever I am
sent, and my happiness will
be supreme. Especially if
you consent to go with me-
Ah! what would I not
give, if you were only here!
How happy I should be! And
what delightful trips we would
take to New York City! But
never mind, I can forego pres-
ent happiness for the joy
which is to be hereafter! Don't
you let some young gentle-
man come along & “cut me
out,” or I shall wish that
I had ne'er been born- Per-
haps the best way for me to
avoid this, is to drop a line
occassionally to somebody's
Mama! Be careful or you may
hear something surprising!
No! No! I'll retract you all of
that- Bless your darling heart!
I am willing to trust you any-
where, & I ought to know bet-
ter than to try to tease you.
I must tell you of a dream that
I had, last night. What do you
suppose it was? Well, I dream-
ed that I was married! As
you live, it was so- & oh!
imagine my horror when I
knew that I was marrying a lady who
was not a North Carolin-
ian! I was never more mis-
erable, & in vain ransacked
my brain to find out the
explanation- Oh! these crazy
dreams! How I dread them!
simply because they make
me so unhappy untill I can
manage to awake- Really, if I
had to have another such
dream, I should not care to
ever sleep again- They say,
however, that dreams go by
contraries, which means that
I will marry a North Caro-
linian! Well, be it so!
In my last letter, I promised to
tell you some good news in
this one. It may seem a little
vanity on my part to think
that you will consider it
as “good” news -- But to the
news. I find that it is per-
fectly allowable for the Com-
mander of a military Post
to grant a leave of absence
for one week, without con-
sulting, in any way, the De-
partment at Washington-
And as we have the most
obliging commander in the
Army, I will certainly be able
to visit you in the fall-
There is no trouble whatever
about getting the leave- The
only think likely to prevent
me from coming, is that I
may be ordered away from
here to a Post so far away
that 7 days would be of no
use to me -- This is not at all
likely- Still I mention what
may possibly occur- Be-
lieve me, my precious E., I
am looking forward with
much pleasure to my next
trip- What delightful con-
versations we will have!
I know I appeared very
stupid (pronounced “stoopid”)
when I was last in Mur-
freesboro, but I trust I shall
give you no cause to com-
plain when I next come.
Forgive me this time, and I'll
try to be brighter next time.
And then such drives! as
Murfreesboro alone can afford-
There will be no trouble about
buggies either! I will have all
such minor matters arranged
before hand -- and I'll not let
my hat blow off again, if
there is such a thing as keep-
ing it on! Ah! that will be
an occassion long to be re-
membered, & it will soon come-
Have not received a letter from
you as yet, but am expecting
one soon- I am going to N.Y.
City tomorrow & will see what
the delay of the “Art Journal”
is due to & have it rectified at
once- If matters do not go right,
I shall certainly call for Charles!
The latter individual, by the way, is
vividly remembered; due to the
sweet messages which he was
wont to bring me.
